That 7 day forecast made me think of WTNV.

Let’s go to the seven-day outlook.

Your daily shades of the sky forecast:

Monday: Turquoise
Tuesday: Taupe
Wednesday: Robin’s egg
Thursday: Turquoise/taupe
Friday: Coal dust
Saturday: Coal dust with chances of indigo in the late afternoon
Sunday: Void

The size and age of the Cosmos are beyond ordinary human understanding.

Lost somewhere between immensity and eternity is our tiny planetary home.

In a cosmic perspective, most human concerns seem insignificant, even petty.

And yet our species is young and curious and brave and shows much promise.

In the last few millennia we have made the most astonishing and unexpected discoveries about the Cosmos and our place within it, explorations that are exhilarating to consider.

They remind us that humans have evolved to wonder, that understanding is a joy, that knowledge is prerequisite to survival.

I believe our future depends on how well we know this Cosmos in which we float like a mote of dust in the morning sky.

― Carl Sagan, Cosmos

It is important to note that the multiverse by it's very nature, space-times outside our own, is untestable and a hypothesis that we have no evidence for. Not even an explanatory mechanism for what generates the multiverse and it's variable constants and physical laws. Therefore, the multiverse theory is a Metaphysical proposition. literally outside our physics.

Secondly, living in a simulated reality is also an untestable hypothesis. And we sould not deny the reality of our experiences unless and until we have reasons and evidence to do so. This is the only rational choice. (Also this seems like another Metaphysical hypothesis.)

Both of these are interesting ideas but are untestable hypothesis' for which we have no evidence for. They are sensational ideas which are popular but have very little going for them, except they may have some explanitory power with regards to the fine tuning problem, that our particular space-time seems incomprehensibly well suited for intelligent life to evolve.
...because scientists making claims based on actual observations is so eighteen-steamengine. Way to go future.

ok, a couple things. if the universe is all smooth and even, why have they mapped the universe to have dense filaments of stellar activity contrasted by near empty regions in space? that seems the opposite of totally smooth.

another point. the multiverse. there are 2 versions of this term floating around. one is as you showed, universes spaced out side by side. the other is where parallel alternate universes spring out of every possible decision we could make. these are 2 totally different multiverse options.

in the 2nd one, the view is also that we are constantly moving from one parallel reality frame to another and we basically determine the future of the world we live in.

Big Bounce is the most cheery?  No.  In a Big Bounce scenario, everything is destroyed in a Big Crunch. In a Big Freeze scenario, Freeman Dyson has calculated that intelligent life can have infinite experience, provided it learns to translate itself into analog rather than digital form.  The Big Freeze is not scary at all.  We just have to learn to adapt and we have trillions of years to learn.

For true science and inquiry please be open minded and examine the creationist, intelligent design, viewpoint of a young earth and a young universe. In other words is there any real scientific proof for evolution either cosmic, chemical and later human.

Monday: Showers with a chance of new dimensions forming
Tuesday: Cloudy with a 45% chance of time flowing backwards
Wednesday: Sunny with a 50% chance of a black hole storm
Thursday: Lightning with a chance of Cthulhu sighting
Friday: Thunder showers with a chance of a simulation glitch
Saturday: Cloudy with a chance of absolute zero
Sunday: Windy with a possibility of a vicious atom shredding

Isn't the bigger something is the faster it moves and the lower it's orbital frequency? - I don't think this is a fixed relationship (and leads to a godel rotating universe idea - that doesn't appear to be what we've actually got) but, using that as an exponentially increasing phenomena then it pretty much works for both 'inflation' and 'accelerated expansion' under one unifying law (and also incorporates the effect of dark matter in galaxies). Thank you for bringing back the space/cosmic side of crash course.  I have not been impressed with some of the other themes that have been created.

Here's another reasons to study this:  so we all believe the same things.  If we are all living out of the same narrative, we will get along better.  Another name for this is brainwashing.  I'm a public high school biology teacher, and I've come to realize that this is my primary job:  to get young people to buy into this narrative that (a) there is competition for jobs, (b) you need to get a good education to make yourself the best qualified for those jobs and (c) if you don't, you will have a miserable life.  Education is offered up as the key to success and happiness; it is offered up as a Savior, a God, to be worshiped and adored.  And all those who are educated are superior to those who are not.  For example, if I were to tell you that I don't believe in the narrative described in this series, many would say that I am an ignorant, uneducated creationist.  I would be labeled, and dismissed.  The arrogance and narcissism of the academic elite is what scares me.  They won't even admit that all of these facts in their narrative are tentative hypotheses that cannot be verified; they are observations - not conclusions.  So that's what really gets me; I'm the one who is actually displaying some intellectual virtues by thinking deeply and thoroughly - they're just regurgitating whatever the scientists say they believe (which in the context of science is a word that should never be used, am I right?  "Believe"... science means "to know").  The Truth is, that this narrative of atheistic cosmic evolution is just another religion; you don't know these things, you can't prove them, so you believe them... that's a religion.  Just admit it; and stop passing it off as "science".  Whatever.  Let me get back to my brainwashing...

I feel like its important to state that the idea of a multiverse and cosmic evolution is little more than mere conjecture.  We don't know so much.... its important to toss out conjectures to give us testable hypotheses, but we shouldn't see them as true till we have a bit more evidence than "its possible from our current model".  When we don't even know where or what the majority of mass in the universe is, or why expansion is still happening... how can we even say our speculations on these larger ideas have any intellectual weight.

I don't think that Cosmic Evolution can form a coherent societal story, at least not in the way that mythology does. The data is far too devoid of meaning until we layer baseless interpretations on top. For example, you say that the Big Bounce is the cheeriest possibility for the eventual fate of the Universe. But why? If you look at this from a slightly more pessimistic angle, and it's not hard to do so, it becomes an endless cycle of suffering. It seems better to just let the Universe grow old and die.

Thank you for creating this follow-up series. The "when will we ever use this?" perspective of education has always bugged me. Robots are super great at only doing one thing. Do you want to be a robot? I sure don't. I want to learn the what, why, and how of EVERYTHING (except that I'd have to be immortal for that). I was also sad that only one of the main hypotheses about the eventual end of the Universe was covered in the first series. It's funny: the Big Bounce is kinda hopeful, the Big Rip is terrifying, and the Big Freeze is just depressing and hopeless. I'm sure we'll all be super-advanced non-physical beings by then, so maybe we could actually experience it. That'd be cool.

Also - and I hate saying this, because I know the frustrations of being a female scientist, but it's true - your haircut is really cute.
